_comment: Abbreviated example of a gap analysis contribution. Full version would have more key_findings, key_papers, gaps, and agenda items.

metadata.title: Effects of Video Assistant Referee (VAR) on Match Outcomes and Player Behavior

submitted_by.user_context: MSc student at Erasmus University exploring thesis topic on VAR and disciplinary cards

scope.research_question: What are the effects of VAR on yellow/red cards, fouls, goals, home advantage, and other match aspects across football competitions?
scope.boundaries: Focus on empirical studies measuring VAR effects on match statistics. Excludes purely legal, technological (CV/AI), or fan-perception studies unless they include match outcome data.

key_findings.finding: VAR introduction is associated with a decrease in yellow cards and fouls in Serie A and Bundesliga
key_findings.effect_size: statistically significant decrease (exact d not reported)

key_findings.finding: VAR has no significant effect on total goals scored or home advantage across 9,076 matches
key_findings.effect_size: near-zero effect across 20 competitions in meta-analysis

key_papers.title: How does Video Assistant Referee (VAR) modify the game in elite soccer?
key_papers.contribution: First large-scale empirical study of VAR effects on cards, fouls, goals, and playing time across two major leagues.

key_papers.title: Meta-analysis of VAR on goals and home advantage
key_papers.contribution: Largest VAR study (9,076 matches, 20 competitions). Finds no significant effect on goals or home advantage.

research_landscape.methodological_patterns: Dominated by pre-post comparisons (1-2 seasons). Only one meta-analysis exists. No RCTs (infeasible). Qualitative work on referee psychology emerging but small.

gaps.title: No longitudinal study of VAR effects beyond 2 seasons
gaps.description: All existing studies compare 1-2 seasons before/after VAR. With 7+ seasons of VAR data now available in multiple leagues, no study has examined whether initial effects (e.g., fewer yellow cards) persist, amplify, or disappear over time.
gaps.suggested_approach: Interrupted time series analysis across 7+ seasons in 10+ European leagues

gaps.title: No cross-competition meta-analysis specifically on disciplinary cards
gaps.description: Rogerson (2024) meta-analyzed goals and home advantage but NOT cards or fouls. No study has pooled card data across competitions to estimate the overall VAR effect on discipline.
gaps.suggested_approach: Random-effects meta-analysis on yellow/red card rates from 15+ competitions

gaps.title: VAR effects in women's football virtually unstudied
gaps.description: Only Stone (2025) examines VAR in women's football (UEFA Women's Champions League). Effects may differ due to different foul frequencies, playing styles, and referee cultures.
gaps.suggested_approach: Comparative pre-post analysis in women's leagues that adopted VAR

research_agenda.title: Longitudinal meta-analysis of VAR effects on cards and fouls across European football
research_agenda.research_question: How do yellow/red card rates change over 7 seasons post-VAR introduction across 10+ European leagues?
research_agenda.data_requirements: FBref/WhoScored season-level card averages per league (2014-2026), 10+ leagues, ~40,000+ matches

strengths: Based on 19 directly relevant papers from the platform database
Includes the only existing meta-analysis on VAR (Rogerson 2024)
Gaps are concrete and addressable with publicly available data
limitations: Analysis limited to papers indexed in the Living Sports Analytics database
Agent cannot access full-text PDFs, analysis based on abstracts and metadata
Non-English language papers may be underrepresented
coverage_gaps: Working papers and preprints on SSRN or arXiv may contain relevant VAR studies not yet in the database
Conference proceedings from sports science conferences may be missing
